Name: ANUTA
Comment: Polygons for Anuta is in the sea and the closest land harbours the language Anuta

Name: Bakumpai Malay
Comment: Polygon is in very far south in the speaker area (according their L42 map in Wurm & Hattori 1981 and other sources)

Name: Bazaar Malay
Comment: Polygon corresponds to the subfamily Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, Aru (the 1981 published maps have no language Polygon that corresponds to this one)

Name: DJAWI
Comment: Polygon encircles Augustus Island while Glottolog coordinate is on Sunday Island. Sunday Island and a few other islands in the Buccaneer archipelago are correct (Bowern 2012) but Augustus Island, a bit too far to the east, is not correct. It is now uninhabited but was inhabited by Worora [wro] until 1950. The W&H L023 map indeed does not show Djawi on Augustus island, so difficult to see how the association appeared. Thus the Polygon should either be attached to Worora [wra] or removed.

Name: GRAND VALLEY DANY, lower of Valley
KAIRIRU
Islands: Papua New Guinea; apua New Guinea

Name: KENINGAU MURUT Dialects / Apin - Aoin Kuijau
KENINGAU MURUT Dialects / Apin - Apin Kuijar
KENINGAU MURUT Dialects / Dusun Murut, Tambual
LUN DAYE p., Kawang - Menadong sd.
MALAY
Sovereigns: Eastern Malaysia; Malaysia; North-Eastern Malaysia; North-Western Malaysia; Southern Malaysia; Urak Lawoi'

Name: P. Batu
Comment: Polygon corresponds to the Sajau Basap n 3 area of their L041 map. Sajau Basap is explained in the text to include Punan Sajau, Punan Basap and Punan Batu 2 hence the (erroneous) association with Punan Batu 1. The area matches that of the real area of the Sajau-Latti (also as per the Glottolog coordinate) and should (also) be linked to Sajau-Latti instead.

Name: PHANG
Comment: Polygon is in a very southern location in Thailand in contrast to the northern location of Glottolog. The location in Thailand is represents a recent refugee population and is in this sense not wrong but the Glottolog location is historically and demographically more accurate.

Name: SANGIR
Comment: Polygon is on mainland Manado, a possible southernmost location

Name: SHAN
Comment: Shan is a relatively disconnected language.

Name: SHAN
Comment: Shan is a relatively disconnected language.

Name: SILA
Comment: Polygon is in the SW most speaker area and Glottolog coordinate in a more central and historically ancestral location.

Name: TAUSUG
Comment: Tausug is spoken over a large disconnected area, Polygon is in a central dialect and Glottolog coordinate somewhat western.

Name: THAVUNG
Comment: Thavung is spoken in different locations, the Polygon is the Laos location which is derivative of the Thailand location reflected in Glottolog's coordinate.

Name: UGONG
Comment: The area of the Ugong is receding and the Polygon is in one of the locations where the language was recently spoken.

Name: West Bird's Head Stock Level Family
YIRANDHALI
Comment: Polygon is the area indeed called Yiradhali on the L022 map. Glottolog coordinate is to the north and east. This is a difficult area but the last revision of by Breen 2009 says that the northern part of the area of the Yirandhali Polygon is Yirandhali (whose heartland is to the north and east like the Glottolog coordinate) but the southern part is Yiningayi which in Glottolog belong to the SE neighbour language Bidyara [bym].
